data.title: Best Movies About Italy: 25 Movies Set in Italy To Watch Before You Go — Travlinmad Slow Travel Blog
data.meta_description: These 25 movies set in Italy — some of the best movies about Italy, and filmed on location there — will stay with you and inspire you to go! They make it look irresistible, and will have you dreaming and scheming of your next trip to Italy!
data.text:
Dreaming of Italy? These 25 of the best movies about Italy — movies set in Italy, about Italy, filmed on location there, and one even about the food — will inspire you to go!

If you love to travel and are always thinking about your next destination, seeing certain movies can inspire you to take action — dust off the old travel guides, jump online, and start planning your escape.

You know what I'm talking about. Work that Italian bucket list!

It's called wanderlust travel, and it's really a thing! Movies, photographs, books, and stories can make you want to travel!

The most inspiring travel movies usually aren't even about traveling at all, but are set in gorgeous locations made even more stunning by professional cinematography.

This post contains affiliate links: if you make a purchase, we may earn a small commission at no extra cost to you.

Movies Set in Italy

We love Italy — it's where our families came from and it always feels like home.

So naturally we’re drawn to movies set in Italy or movies about Italy, even if they weren’t filmed entirely in Italy.

Here is your list of must-see movies set in Italy, about Italy, and even about the food!

We watch them on Repeat whenever we need a healthy dose of Bologna, Venice, or the Dolomites of northern Italy, or Tuscany, Napoli, and the Amalfi Coast.

Even after you’ve returned from a trip to Italy, watching movies like these work wonders to help you relive precious memories made, remind you of new friends made, and even inspire you to cook the fabulous food.

This Italy movies list is just what you’ll need to get inspired and make plans, or keep your Italy dreams alive and well.

They make Italy look and feel irresistible, and have us dreaming and planning our next trip. If you love Italy too, or have always dreamt of visiting but have yet to go, plan your first visit.

These 25 movies set in Italy are perfect to watch before you go!

Not only is this a thrilling movie full of mystery and suspense, I watch it again and again when I'm in the mood for Italy.

The cinematography definitely makes the twisted title character played brilliantly by Matt Damon much more tolerable.

One of the best movies about Italy that’s filmed entirely in Italy apart from the opening scenes in New York City, the idyllic Italian film locations include Naples, Positano, Venice, Rome, and Sicily, though some of my favorite are in Ischia, a small island destination off the coast of Campania.

Despite it's suspenseful plot, it shows Italy (and hunky Matt Damon and Jude Law) at its best with so many quiet areas that many tourists never get to see, unless you get off the beaten path!

Rent on Amazon Prime

Buy the Rolled Movie Poster!

Pane e Tulipani ("Bread and Tulips") is a warmhearted comedy about love, family, and friendship.

We hadn’t seen the movie until last year after friends in Italy actually recommended seeing it. We thought if they were recommending it, it must be good.

At the very least, it must present Italy in a way that even Italians enjoyed! Plus, the film garnered tons of awards at the Cannes Film Festival, Toronto Film Festival, and a slew of Italy film awards including the Italy Golden Globe award for.

What a delightful film. So good, in fact, we secretly daydreamed someone would accidentally leave us in Italy!

Rent on Amazon Prime!

As a young boy Salvatore discovers the perfect escape in his war-torn Sicilian village, the Cinema Paradiso movie house.

Over time the projectionist, Alfredo, fosters in him a love of films.

When Salvatore is of age he falls in love, and takes over as the Paradiso's projectionist.

But Alfredo’s work is not done as he tries to convince Salvatore to leave his small town and pursue his passion for films and filmmaking.

Cinema Paradiso was shot on location in Bagheria, Sicily, and Cefalù on the Tyrrhenian Sea., and in the village of Palazzo Adriano south of Palermo.

At the 62nd Academy Awards the film won the Best Foreign Language Film.

Buy on Amazon

Buy a rolled Cinema Paradiso movie poster!

If you’re a lover of Italian antiquities, this movie is a must-see.

Set against the stunning warm backdrop of Rome, the sequel to Dan Brown’s epic novel The DaVinci Code, almost feels like an inside glimpse, a skip-the-line access or backstage pass to the Vatican and the Secret Archives as well as some of the Eternal City’s most breathtaking and lesser-known works of art.

The film’s subplot also serves as a sort of art history guide and walking tour of the statues and obelisks along the four altars of the Path of Illumination.

Finally, there’s Tom Hanks…and what film isn’t made better by that guy!

Rent on Amazon Prime!

Buy a Rolled Movie Poster!

After a $35 million gold heist in Venice, Steve turns on his partners murdering one in the process and decides to keep all the gold for himself.

His former partners vow revenge and enlist the help of Steve’s daughter to recover the gold kept from his mansion.

Most of the film was shot on location in Venice and Los Angeles, though the chase sequences were filmed in in the Coventry district in England, and Turin and parts of northern Italy north of Venice and around the Dolomites.

I dare you to watch these scenes and not want to head out on an Italy road trip.

This movie is a must see for action fans who enjoy plot twists and turns, though we’ve had more than a few comments on this post from those who think the original 1969 film starring Michael Caine is the better of the two. Let me know which is your pick!

Rent on Amazon Prime

This touching rom-com is worth seeing if you’re planning to visit Verona while you’re in Italy (and you should).

Plan on stopping by Juliet’s balcony in historic Old Town in the medieval city of Verona, the setting for Shakespeare’s famous love tragedy Romeo and Juliet.

Although no one really knows for certain how authentic or historically accurate the balcony really is, there’s no denying it’s one of the biggest tourist traps in all of Italy.

But just in case it really is her balcony, don’t you want to see it just this once?

The rest of Verona is also worth seeing, though you’ll see references throughout the city to the play.

7. Il Postino (The Postman)

(1994)

OVERVIEW: A light drama that stars Massimo Troisi, Philippe Noiret, Maria Grazia Cucinotta.

A simple Italian postman learns to love poetry while delivering mail to a famous poet, and then uses this to woo local beauty Beatrice.

Neruda receives so much mail that Mario, an unemployed do-nothing is hired as a postman. He has only one thing to do, deliver Neruda’s mail.

Mario becomes engrossed in the art of poetry and uses his newfound interest to impress a young and beautiful barmaid, Beatrice.

He uses poetry to tell of the struggles of working class villagers and in the process becomes a changed man.

The mid-life crisis premise may be cliche, but Eat, Pray, Love is still one of my favorites that'll have you thinking for weeks about finding your peace in India, your pizza in Italy, and love in Bali.

The Italian scenery and the food is the reason this movie set in Italy stays with you for so long.

Actually, the scenery in all three of these places is stunning, but just wait until you see the Italian food! It’s one of those films that’ll have you dreaming about traveling to Italy just for the food.

And the variety of Roman dishes that Julia Roberts scarfs down is enough to make you book a flight today.

From prosciutto e melon and Jewish-style Roman carciofi (artichokes) to plate after plate of spaghetti al Pomodoro. Nothing a Rome food tour can't cure!

Rent on Amazon Prime!

Buy an Eat Pray Love rolled Movie Poster!

In the end Maximus is able to finally avenge the murders of his family and the murder of his beloved emperor.

Two of the key scenes from the film were filmed in the Val d’Orcia in Tuscany.

Other scenes were filmed in England, Morocco and Malta using recreated settings of Rome.

Two key scenes from the film were filmed in the beautiful Tuscany Val d’Orcia, while others scenes were filmed in England, Morocco, and Malta.

The Tuscany scenes, along with the haunting soundtrack, are set in one of the most picturesque spots in all of all Italy, the peaceful green Orcia Valley is a direct contrast to the noise and bloodlust in Rome.

With fields of rolling wheat dotted here and there by stately columnar cypress trees winding the roads leading up to stone farmhouses, Gladiator is worth watching just for the incredible Italy scenery.

Rent on Amazon Prime

Buy an original rolled Gladiator Movie Poster (studio issued)!

The first part of the film is a tender romance story filled with laughs and the warmth of a gentle Italian-Jewish waiter who wants to open a bookshop and eventually wins the heart of the girl of his dreams.

Later, the movie takes a dark turn when the waiter along with his wife and son are sent to a Nazi concentration camp.

Life is Beautiful is a heartfelt story of a father creating games for his young son’s amusement to protect him from the horrors of internment in a concentration camp.

It works well enough until the film’s bittersweet ending.

The film was mostly shot in Arezzo, southeast of Florence in Tuscany. Some scenes were done in nearby Cortona and some in Terni in Umbria.

Critically acclaimed, the film won the Grand Prix at the 1998 Cannes Film Festival, and three Academy Awards including Best Foreign Language Film and Best Actor among its many other awards.

Rent on Amazon Prime

The aging patriarch of an organized crime dynasty transfers control of his empire to his reluctant son Michael.

Michael can not escape being drawn into the world of violence and treachery and rises to power as the ruthless head of a New York crime family.

Along the way his marriage and personal relationships fall apart as he becomes the new Don Corleone.

The film was shot in part in the towns of Savoca and Forza d’Agrò, Sicily.

Regarded as one of the greatest films ever made, the film won the Academy Awards for Best Picture, Best Actor, and Best Adapted Screenplay as well as being nominated in seven other categories.

Rent on Amazon Prime

Buy The Godfather Trilogy: Corleone Legacy Collection (Blu-ray)

In Cremona, Italy, a legendary violin maker crafts a violin in 1681 and paints his creation with the blood of his dead wife to keep her memory alive.

The future of the violin was predicted through an eerie tarot card reading, and indeed changed hands several times over three centuries.

In 1997, the violin turns up in an auction house in Montreal.

It has been shot, buried, nearly burned and stolen more than once. It produces music so beautiful that it has a profound impact on all those who own it.

Samuel L. Jackson’s character Morritz takes the violin as a gift for his daughter leaving a copy in its place.

The Red Violin was shot in Italy, Austria, Canada, China, and England.

Rent on Amazon Prime

Claudio (Robert Sean Leonard) falls in love with our heroine (Kate Beckinsale), and they decide to marry.

Don Pedro's (Denzel Washington) devious half-brother Don John (Keanu Reeves) opposes the match, and he devises a plan to tear the couple apart.

The second couple, Benedick (Kenneth Branagh) and Beatrice (Emma Thompson), are kept apart by their mutual disdain for one another until brought together by Don Pedro who makes them think that they secretly love each other.

The plot is typical Shakespearean romantic comedy complete with misunderstandings, conspiracy, and cruel jokes.

But it’s well done, and the settings in Italy are dreamy and romantic. Much Ado About Nothing was filmed at Villa Vignamaggio, in Greve in Chianti, just 20 miles south of Florence.

Rent on Amazon Prime

Rose Arbuthnot (Miranda Richardson) and Lottie Wilkins (Josie Lawrence) decide to take a break from their spouses with a stay at a castle in Italy.

They are soon joined in Italy by Caroline Dester (Polly Walker) and Mrs. Fisher (Joan Plowright).

Freed from their unhappy lives, the four women are transformed by their new lives in rural Italy.

Enchanted April is one of the movies set in Italy that was filmed entirely on location at Castello Brown in Portofino, on the Ligurian Coast north of the colorful Cinque Terre.

It’s the same castle where the author of the 1922 novel of the same name, Elizabeth von Arnim, stayed in the 1920s.

Rent on Amazon Prime

16. Spettacolo

(2017)

OVERVIEW: Every year, a small town in Tuscany has held a traditional theatre performance, but their population is aging and more young folks have moved away, leaving a lack of amateur talent.

The town responds to their dilemma in an inspiring way.

I saw Spettacolo at the Naples Film Festival (Naples Florida, that is), coincidentally after just having visited the small town of Monticchielo one afternoon while driving around Tuscany.

It was filmed entirely in this idyllic Tuscan village and tells the true story of the townspeople and the Poor Theater of Monticchielo.

This story is filmed against the stunning backdrop of Florence, one of Italy's most iconic cities, and the surrounding Tuscany countryside including the town of San Gimignano.

Not only is the story beautifully portrayed but I also loved the occasional musical reference to Puccini, one of Italy's most enduring Opera composers.

The hotel that’s featured in the film where Charlotte and Lucy stay is the fictional Pensione Bertolini — the real life Hotel degli Orafi, which is located on the banks of the Arno River.

It’s a lovely hotel, and worth a stay for the amazing view alone.

Because when you're in Florence, you always need a room with a view!

Rent on Amazon Prime

Buy a Rolled Movie Poster!

This movie on our Italy movies list is a true classic, and the black and white cinematography is utterly timeless.

This is also the film that's referenced in the Under The Tuscan Sun (below) — Fifi of course refers to director Federico Fellini, and you'll recognize the famous romp in the fountain.

If you love black and white movies and film noir, you have to see this — one of the best movies about Italy!

This movie has also turned into a cult classic because it resonates so deeply with lovers of idyllic Tuscany and dreamy Positano, it'll have you scheming how you can sell everything you own and move to Italy.

The movie was filmed in Italy: in Tuscany, the charming town of Cortona is where Frances lives and renovates her home.

The author still has her home “Bramasole” there, though the movie was actually filmed at nearby Villa Laura in Montepulciano.

In Positano, Marcello’s Apartment is the lovely Hotel California.

The book by the same name is set in Italy, and follows the movie closely.

The story is lighthearted and so identifiable — whether you're newly divorced, left stranded by your lover, caught in a star-crossed love affair, finding love in a foreign land, or longing for lost love.

But no matter your situation, Tuscany and the Amalfi Coast will grab you and never let go!

Rent on Amazon Prime!

Buy the rolled Movie Poster!

This movies with Angelina Jolie and Johnny Depp is easy to like and easy to believe, since it involves a beautiful scheming woman and a man gullible enough to be completely duped on a train. LOL.

But I guess anything is possible once Italy casts its charms!

If you’re planning on train travel through Italy anytime soon, this is major inspiration — the scenes depict the lush and beautiful countryside you can easily imagine your trip will be.

Although the plot quickly reveals itself once they’ve reached Venice, your story will just be getting started, with a happier ending than theirs as well!

Rent on Amazon Prime

Fans of classic films will love this tender study of a crumbling marriage set against the backdrop of the ruins of Pompeii.

There’s a stunning quality about watching Italy in black and white that in many ways is even more beautiful than in color.

Among the most influential films of the postwar era, Journey to Italy (Viaggio in Italia) charts the declining marriage of an unhappily married couple from England (Ingrid Bergman and George Sanders) who travel from London through Italy to Naples where they have inherited a villa.

Katherine feels trapped in a loveless marriage with her ill-tempered husband, Alex, and has made the journey to Italy hoping to rekindle the passion of their marriage. But it is not to be.

Journey To Italy was shot at variety of locations throughout Italy, including Naples, Capri, Pompeii, and in the studio in Rome.

Rent on Amazon Prime

If you're a serious Italy lover or Italy foodie and haven't seen this movie yet, please do yourself a favor and rent it tonight!

This cult classic gives a delicious education on 1) some incredible traditional Italian food, and 2) the intense passion Italians have for their food...food as love... whether you're making it or eating it.

It's a heartwarming story, and the food alone will make you book your next trip, I promise!

If you’re an Italy foodie and love a good movie that has you excited and searching for recipes by the end, you’ll love this movies about Italy and its amazing Italian food culture.

Rent on Amazon Prime!
